ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

PULAU SAKENG
(Resettlement plans)


    1. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for Law (a) whether there is any plan to resettle the residents of Pulau Seking, the only inhabited island of the Southern Islands; and (b) if there is no definite plan for resettlement, whether the Land Office will further enhance maintenance works and provide facilities for the islanders who are mostly senior citizens.

     The Second Minister for Law (Prof. S. Jayakumar): Mr Speaker, Sir, since Pulau Sakeng is not affected by immediate development, there is no plan at present to resettle the residents of the island.

    There are 65 families (about 250 persons) living on the island. They pay TOL fees of only $3 per annum for a dwelling house and $12 per annum for a shop site. Maintenance work such as oiling and anti-malarial work is being carried out by the Ministry of the Environment every week. The clearing of daily refuse is being carried out by the householders on the island either by burning or burying. There is a community centre, a clinic, a police post, a mosque, a Malay school and an Arab school on the island.

    The penghulu who is also residing on the island assists the Land Office in looking after the island and attending to the requirements of the residents. The Land Office has not received any complaints regarding maintenance or requests for additional amenities from the residents directly or through the penghulu. Since the existing maintenance services and amenities provided are satisfactory, there is no plan to provide additional facilities or services.

    For the information of the hon. Member, during the past year some 16 licensees have already moved out of the island to stay on the mainland. It is not cost effective to enhance the facilities in view of the dwindling population on the island.

Column: 792



     Encik Abbas Abu Amin (Pasir Panjang): Sir, would the Minister consider the possibility of an early resettlement of these senior residents? They are now facing a lot of difficulty especially when there is a bereavement, the burial has got to be carried out in the mainland. And there is also the problem of medical facilities. Therefore, I would like to seriously ask the Minister that, as the population is dwindling, whether he will consider an early resettlement of these residents.

     Prof. Jayakumar: Mr Speaker, Sir, I take the point of the Member for Pasir Panjang. As I said, there is no immediate plan for resettlement. But in view of what he has said, I will ask the officials concerned to have another look at the matter.

HOUGANG AVENUE 2
(Pedestrian overhead bridges)


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development whether and when pedestrian overhead bridges will be built at Hougang Avenue 2.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Sir, the HDB has plans to build two overhead pedestrian bridges for Hougang Avenue 2. Work on the first bridge is expected to begin in July and to be completed in December 1987, whilst work on the second bridge is expected to begin in October 1987 and to be completed in March 1988.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Hon. Minister of State where will these two overhead pedestrian bridges be located?

WIDENING OF JALAN KAYU AND SELETAR ROAD/
ANG MO KIO NEW TOWN LINK


    3. Mr Heng Chiang Meng asked the Minister for National Development whether there are plans to (i) widen Jalan Kayu and (ii) connect Seletar Road directly to Ang Mo Kio New Town.

     Dr Lee Boon Yang (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Public Works Department has no plan to widen Jalan Kayu as the traffic volume along the road is still low.

    The Public Works Department does not favour linking Seletar Road directly with Ang Mo Kio New Town. While the link would provide a convenient access for the residents in Seletar Road area to the New Town, it would also encourage extraneous traffic to use Seletar Road, and this would be detrimental to the quiet environment of the residential areas.

     Mr Heng Chiang Meng (Jalan Kayu): Sir, may I ask the Minister of State that, as long as these reasons are valid, may I have his assurance that there will be no plan to link Seletar Road with Ang Mo Kio New Town? And secondly, should there be such a plan, would he seek the opinion of the Member of Parliament for the area?

     Dr Lee Boon Yang: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, as I said, PWD is in favour of retaining the quiet environment of the neighbourhood. Therefore, unless there are unexpected changes or pressing need, it is unlikely that the Department would want to make the connection of these roads. But when the need arises, I am sure the Department will consult the Member of Parliament for that area.

ADMISSION OF '0' LEVEL STUDENTS INTO TERTIARY INSTITUTIONS
(Figures)


    4. Dr Ow Chin Hock asked the Minister for Education, of the 'O' level students who were eligible for higher education in 1985

Column: 794

and 1986, how many per cent were admitted into (i) junior colleges, (ii) Pre-University centres and (iii) Polytechnics.

     The Minister of State for Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the Minister for Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    Sir, in 1985, 22,725 '0' level certificate holders were eligible for higher education. Of these, 9,522 or 42% were admitted to junior colleges, 2,568 or 11% were admitted to pre-university centres and 6,113 or 26.9% to the polytechnics. The corresponding figures for 1986 are as follows: 19,686 were eligible for higher education, 10,591 or 54% went on to junior colleges, 2,716 or 14% went on to pre-university centres and 5,279 or 26.8% went on to polytechnics.

MOSQUE BUILDING PROGRAMME
(Progress report)


    5. Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe asked the Minister for the Environment if he will (i) report on the progress of the mosques to be developed under Phase Two of the Mosque Building Fund Programme and (ii) consider allowing funds available in the Mosque Building Fund, after the completion of the Phase Two mosques, to be used for renovations and improvements to the older mosques.

     The Minister for the Environment (Dr Ahmad Mattar): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, nine mosques have been planned under Phase II of the Mosque Building Programme. Two have been completed and are in use, namely, Masjid En-Naeem at Hougang and Masjid Darul Aman at Kampong Ubi. Two more mosques will be completed by the third quarter of this year. They are Masjid Darul Makmur at Yishun and Masjid Al-Mukminin at Jurong East. Another two mosques are under construction and will be completed in 1988, namely, Masjid Darussalam at Clementi and Masjid Al-Amin at Telok Blangah.

    Tenders have been called for the construction of Masjid Darul Ghufran at Tampines New Town and the HDB is finalizing the designs of the remaining two mosques at Siglap and Bukit Batok. Tenders are scheduled to be called this

Column: 795

year and we can expect the mosques to be completed by 1989.

    Sir, the request of the Member for Geylang Serai to allow funds available in the Mosque Building Fund to be used for renovations and improvements to the old mosques cannot be considered. This is because the Administration of Muslim Law Act provides that the monies in the Mosque Building Fund shall be used for the purpose of building mosques only. I would also like to add, Sir, that on completion of Phase II of the Mosque Building Programme, MUIS will embark on Phase III as there are new HDB estates which have to be provided with mosques for its Muslim residents.

     Encik Othman bin Haron Eusofe (Geylang Serai): Sir, I would like to ask some supplementary questions on the development of Masjid Darul Ghufran in Tampines. Is the Minister aware that the Darul Ghufran Building Committee has expressed great unhappiness over the architectural designs of the Darul Ghufran Mosque? Is he also aware that, after several discussions with MUIS and also with the architects in charge of the project, they have submitted proposals to improve the architectural designs? Up to this date, I think there has been no reply from the HDB. Would the Minister assist the Committee in asking MUIS, as well as the architects in charge, to consider the proposed architectural designs positively and expeditiously? In my view, the designs would help enhance the architecture of the Mosque.

     Dr Ahmad Mattar: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, the Mosque Building Committee of Masjid Darul Ghufran in Tampines have asked for the inclusion of minarets and Islamic motifs for the windows. They have also asked for the open space on the second storey of the mosque to be covered to provide a larger prayer area for the ladies. Sir, I am told that the HDB is prepared to consider favourably the inclusion of a minaret and Islamic motifs for the square windows but they cannot accede to the request to cover the open space on the second storey because this would give rise to ventilation problems.

HAWKER STALLS OPERATING HALF A DAY
(Figures)


    6. Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon asked the Minister for the Environment how many hawker stalls are presently opened for only part of a day on a permanent basis and whether he will consider allowing new applicants for hawker licences to share such stalls.

     The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment (Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng) (for the Minister for the Environment): Sir, I am replying on behalf of my Minister.

    Some cooked food hawkers who operate alongside a wet market do close their stalls in the afternoon because there are no customers in the afternoon when the wet market is closed. Some food stalls do not operate in the night for the same reason that there are no customers. My Ministry estimates that there are about 1,600 hawkers in these two categories who operate for part of the day only. This is about 18% of the total number of hawkers. I believe most stallholders will conduct business when there is business to be made.

    My Ministry is not in favour of allowing two licensees to share a stall as this will give rise to disputes, say, which licensee is to be held responsible when the Ministry finds the stall dirty and insanitary. It is also not feasible nor is it practicable for two licensees to share a stall because the stall is small; there is not enough storage space to accommodate two sets of cooking utensils; it is not practical for the hawker to remove his appliances and utensils after he has finished his business and to bring these back to the stall when he resumes business the next day.

     Mrs Yu-Foo Yee Shoon (Yuhua): Sir, will the Ministry allow two licensed hawkers of the same trade to share a stall if they have mutually agreed to do so? The second question is: since the Ministry is not going to build any new hawker centre, in order to allow those who need to operate a food stall for a living, will the Ministry allow private developers to build hawker centres?

Column: 797



     Mr Eugene Yap Giau Cheng: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, in answer to the first question, the suggestion seems interesting enough. I will ask my officers to look into it. As regards the private development of hawker centres, there is already some arrangement of this sort. They are at Changi Hawker Centre, Scotts, Forum Galeria, and others. I do not see any reason why my Ministry should object to a group of private developers wanting to develop a hawker centre and run the business.

REDUCED TAS TARIFFS
(Revenue loss)


    7. Mr Yeo Choo Kok asked the Minister for Communications and Information (a) whether he will inform the House about the reduction in tariffs that the Telecommunication Authority of Singapore had made to help businesses stay competitive; (b) what is the loss in revenue as a result of such reduction; and (c) whether more reductions are to be made in 1988.

     The Minister for Communications and Information (Dr Yeo Ning Hong): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, since 1979, Telecoms has revised its tariff rates for international telephone and telex services eight times. Today, our businessmen pay one of the lowest international telephone and telex tariff rates in the world.

    As a result of the tariff reductions, cumulatively more than $1.5 billion has been passed back to the consumers over the past seven years. In 1986 alone, an additional $19 million was passed back to the economy when Telecoms revised its tariff rates for international telephone and telex, radio paging and postal services. In addition, the sales scheme implemented recently for mobile telephones, radio pagers and facsimile machines and the liberalization of the maintenance of private switching equipment will result in another $10 million savings in rentals which will be passed back to the consumers.

    Telecoms will continually review its tariff rates and will pass back to its consumers any cost savings achieved through economies of scale, productivity gains and

Column: 798

technological advancement. For the financial year 1987/88, Telecoms will review yet again the tariff rates, particularly for Telepac and Telefax services. Hopefully, this could result in some cost reduction to businessmen for the transmission of data, messages and correspondence.

     Mr Yeo Choo Kok (Delta): Sir, if the TAS is to privatize, will the consumers continue to benefit from these cost savings?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, if the TAS is privatized, it will have to depend on the decision of the private company running the Telecoms services.

BUONA VISTA MRT STATION
(Progress)


    8. Encik Abbas Abu Amin asked the Minister for Communications and Information what is the progress of the Mass Rapid Transit system in respect of Buona Vista Station and whether there will be any provision for taxi stands or bus terminus for shuttle service.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, structural work on the Buona Vista station has been completed. Architectural works are half completed and electrical and mechanical works have just started. Buona Vista station which is along the MRT line from Yio Chu Kang to Clementi is expected, as I have indicated a few days earlier, to be operational by April 1988.

    Taxi stands will be provided at the Buona Vista station. The HDB will also be building a bus interchange next to the station. This is expected to be completed by the end of 1988. In the meantime, a temporary bus interchange will be built by the HDB to service the station when it opens.

NEIGHBOURHOOD POLICE POST IN EUNOS CRESCENT ESTATE


    9. Encik Wan Hussin bin Hj Zoohri asked the Minister for Home Affairs if he will expedite the setting up of a neighbourhood police post in Eunos Crescent Estate.

Column: 799



     The Minister of State for Home Affairs (Dr Lee Boon Yang) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    The Neighbourhood Police Post in Kampong Ubi Constituency will be established this year. It will be located at the void deck of Block 9 Eunos Crescent and construction will commence by early May 1987. It is expected to be operational in October this year.

LIBRARY IN HOUGANG NEW TOWN


    10. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Community Development whether and when a public library will be built in Hougang New Town.

     The Minister for Community Development (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Sir, the National Library has no plan to build a branch library in Hougang New Town currently. The first National Library five-year development plan will end in FY 87. Between now and then, two new branch libraries will be built in Jurong East and Geylang East. The National Library will consider the need for a branch library in Hougang when it draws up its second development plan for 1988-1992.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting:Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, can I ask the Hon. Minister, why does it take so long for the National Library to draw up such plans to build branch libraries elsewhere?

     Mr Wong Kan Seng:The first development plan was drawn up a few years ago and it was for a five-year period. After this five-year development plan has been completed and implemented, then the second five-year plan will be developed. We are now discussing with the Treasury officials to develop the second five-year plan. The Finance Ministry will be looking into the norms and the criteria for the building of branch libraries. So this is under review.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting:In that case, will consideration be given to the size of Hougang New Town which will have some 40,000 units when completed? In other words, can I ask the Hon. Minister to request the National Library to make provision for a branch library to be built in Hougang New Town, say, after 1992?

Column: 800



     Mr Wong Kan Seng:Yes. As I have said, we will consider the development and the building of a library in Hougang New Town under the second five-year plan. Definitely, if all goes well, the Member is likely to have a new branch library in Hougang after 1990.

INFLATION IN 1987


    11. Mr Chew Heng Ching asked the Minister for Trade and Industry if he will give the outlook for inflation in Singapore in 1987.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong):Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, Singapore experienced an inflation rate of minus 1.4% in 1986, the first annual decline in a decade. This disinflation was mainly attributed to the lower cost of food, clothing, housing and transport and communications. Almost half of the overall decline was contributed by oil-related items following the world-wide oil glut.

    Negative inflation is unlikely to be repeated in 1987. Most countries are anticipating higher inflation rates as they project higher prices of primary commodities and oil in 1987. As Singapore depends to a large extent on imported products, we cannot be isolated from the influence of higher inflation in other countries. Based on these assumptions, MTI forecasts an inflation rate of about 1% this year.

     Mr Chew Heng Ching (Kaki Bukit): Sir, may I ask the Minister whether the anticipated take-off in economic activity this year, which will result in a greater demand for goods and services, will have any likely impact on the inflation outlook which he has just painted?

     BG Lee Hsien Loong:Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, it depends. Most of our demand is external demand. The goods are sold overseas. The feedback is not into the prices within Singapore. There would be feedback within Singapore if wage increases, for example, are faster than productivity increases, so that workers are paid more than the value of the goods and the services which they produce. When too much money goes round chasing too few goods, inflation goes up. On present trends, there is no sign of that. Our unions

Column: 801

are extremely reasonable. Wage settlements have been extremely moderate and, as Members have been informed by the Minister for Finance, last year wage increases were negligible, less than 1%. So I do not see any risk of that this year.

     Mr Chiam See Tong (Potong Pasir):Thank you, Mr Chairman. I said at the close of the last sitting of this House that our local journalists are a talented lot. They are good. But unfortunately, as I have mentioned, they cannot work objectively because of the difficult conditions in which they have to work and they have to work also under difficult constraints. I believe they are unable to exercise their own professional judgment, in particular on political and other sensitive matters. That is the very reason why they cannot be objective.

    I was about to cite an example the last time when the time was up. This is the case of a very senior journalist. I believe he was also a sub-editor in the Straits Times. He specializes in political reporting. I came to know of him the first time only when I entered the political arena. But before that I was reading his articles and I thought that he had a high proficiency in his craft and I respected him for that. The first time I met him was when he attended our first press conference of my Party. In fact, I felt flattered to have his presence.

Column: 802



    Then there was this bye-election in 1981. My Party and I were active at that bye-election and I believe this very senior reporter was also doing his work at Anson. And I am sure he knew the mood of the voters just as I knew the ground at that time. My assessment of the situation was that there was a 50-50 chance for the Opposition to win and I am sure that senior reporter also knew that. But on polling day, what did he write? Under his own name, he reported in the front page of the Straits Times under this headline, "PAP will win". That was his assessment of the situation. Of course, we know the result. The PAP candidate lost and that candidate has never been heard of since. But that is another matter.

    Where was the objectivity of that reporter? Where was his professionalism?

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, on a point of clarification. If the Member is going to run down an individual outside of this House, I suggest he be man enough to repeat whatever he said outside the House.

     Some hon. Members: Hear, hear!

     Mr Chiam See Tong: What exactly do you want me to repeat that I have said in this House and I will repeat it, please.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Whatever you have just said.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: What is it that you want me to repeat? I have said so many things. As you know, in a libel case you must state the exact words.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, it is not honourable for the Member to stand in the House with all the immunity that the House provides him and for him to run down ---

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I will repeat it if I know the exact words. Don't get me wrong.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: The exact words can be read back to you rightaway.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: All right. What is it that you want me to repeat? Let me know.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Can you please give us the words that have been said, the last

Column: 803

portion about the senior reporter who is a sub-editor and did not report objectively? Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, according to my recollection, the Member was talking about a sub-editor who had a point of view and then reported differently, not objectively.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: If you will just repeat the words, I will take it down and I will repeat it outside.

     An hon. Member: You said it.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I will repeat that. I have got nothing to fear.

     Dr Koh Lip Lin: Outside this House, not inside.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Please don't show your temper.

     The Leader of the House (Mr Wong Kan Seng): Point of order, Sir. I think we can easily ask the Parliamentary reporter to get those words out at the end of the day. And then we can ask the Member to repeat them, rather than spending so much time arguing about this now.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Mr Chairman, as the Hon. Minister would know, I must know the exact words what he wants me to repeat and I will repeat it outside this House, if they were my words.

     Dr Yeo Ning Hong: Your words have been recorded.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: Let me have the words that you want me to repeat. We cannot have some vague accusations in this House. I will not tolerate that. [Interruptions].

     The Chairman: Order.

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I am saying that there is no objectivity in our press reporting because they are working under certain constraints. And this reporter is an experienced reporter. He has been reporting on political matters for a long time and I am sure he knows of the ground at the Anson bye-election in 1981. And if he knows of the ground, why did he say, in the front page, that the PAP will win? Unless, of course, he is not proficient, which I am not saying that. I am sure he knows exactly what the situation is. I am

Column: 804

saying that our reporters are not able to report objectively because of the constraints in which they have to work under. I believe up till today that senior reporter at the bottom of his heart, I am sure he still felt that Mr Jeyaretnam had a chance to win. But under the constraints in which he was working, he was unable to say that. There is nothing wrong with the majority of our reporters, I have said that.

     The Chairman: Order, Mr Chiam. You are engaging in irrelevant repetition. Could you please proceed with something new or else return to your seat?

     Mr Chiam See Tong: I have said this Government has got two standards. I do not think they will allow any newspaper companies to have an independent editorial policy. They will not allow that. We have seen examples of at least three papers which have suffered the wrath of this Government - Nanyang Siang Pau, The Singapore Herald and the Eastern Sun. But let us look at what the Prime Minister had to say when he was in the Opposition in the Malaysian Parliament. He asked of the Federal Information Minister this question. He asked whether the Minister's duty was to produce closed minds or open minds "because these instruments, the mass media, TV, Radio, can produce either the open mind receptive to ideas and ideals, a democratic system of life or closed limited minds.
